Sanskrit: भवदुःखशतानि तर्तुकामै-रपि सत्त्वव्यसनानि हर्तुकामैः। बहुसौख्यशतानि भोक्तुकामै-र्न विमोच्यं हि सदैव बोधिचित्तम्॥८॥
English 1: Those who wish to destroy the hundreds of sufferings of existence, who desire to dispel the unhappiness of beings, and who wish to experience many hundreds of joys, should never forsake bodhichitta.
English 2: Wishing to destroy the hundred sufferings of existence, desiring to remove the unhappiness of sentient beings, and wishing to experience hundreds of joys, one should never abandon bodhichitta.

Sanskrit: जगदानन्दबीजस्य जगद्दुःखौषधस्य च। चित्तरत्नस्य यत्पुण्यं तत्कथं हि प्रमीयताम्॥२६॥
English 1: The cause of every wanderer's joy, The cure for beings' suffering, How could one take the measure of The merit of this precious mind?
English 2: The source of joy for all beings, the nectar that overcomes the suffering of sentient beings, how can one measure the merit of this precious mind?
Commentary 2: གཉིས་པ་ལ། སྦྱོར་བའི་དམིགས་རྣམ་རྒྱ་ཆེ་བ་དང་། དེ་གཞན་ལ་མེད་པར་བསྟན་པ་གཉིས་ཀྱི། དང་པོ་ནི། འགྲོ་བ་ཀུན་གྱི་དགའ་བའི་རྒྱུ་སེམས་ཅན་ཀྱི་སྡུག་བསྔལ་གྱི་ནད་སེལ་བའི་རྩི་སྨན་དུ་གྱུར་པའི་རིན་ཆེན་སེམས་ཀྱི་བསོད་ནམས་གང་ཡིན་པ་དེ་ལ་ཇི་ལྟར་གཞལ་གྱིས་ལང་སྟེ། དཔལ་བྱིན་གྱིས་ཞུས་པ་ལས། བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་ཀྱི་བསོད་ནམས་གང་། །གལ་ཏེ་དེ་ལ་གཟུགས་མཆིས་ན། །ནམ་མཁའི་ཁམས་ནི་ཀུན་གང་སྟེ། །དེ་བས་ཀྱང་ནི་ལྷག་པར་འགྱུར། །ཞེས་གསུངས་སོ། །

Sanskrit: दुःखमेवाभिधावन्ति दुःखनिःसरणाशया। सुखेच्छयैव संमोहात् स्वसुखं घ्नन्ति शत्रुवत्॥२८॥
English 1: They wish to cast off suffering but rush toward suffering itself. They wish for happiness, but deluded, crush their own pleasure like a foe.
English 2: Though wishing to be free from suffering, they run towards suffering itself. Though desiring happiness, in their ignorance they destroy their own happiness as if it were an enemy.

Sanskrit: यस्तेषां सुखरङ्काणां पीडितानामनेकशः। तृप्तिं सर्वसुखैः कुर्यात्सर्वाः पीडाश्छिनत्ति च॥२९॥
English 1: For those deprived of happiness Who suffer many miseries, This satisfies with every pleasure And severs every suffering.
English 2: For those who are deprived of happiness and endure much suffering, may they be satisfied with all happiness and may all their suffering be eliminated.

Sanskrit: अपायदुःखविश्रामं सर्वसत्त्वैः कृतं शुभम्। अनुमोदे प्रमोदेन सुखं तिष्ठन्तु दुःखिताः॥१॥
English 1: Delighted, I rejoice in virtue— Respite from the pains Of lower realms—and in those who suffer Dwelling in happiness.
English 2: I rejoice with joy in the virtue that relieves the suffering of all beings' lower realms, and in the happiness of those who are suffering.

Sanskrit: संसारदुःखनिर्मोक्षमनुमोदे शरीरिणाम्। बोधिसत्त्वत्वबुद्धत्वमनुमोदे च तायिनाम्॥२॥
English 1: I rejoice in the virtue accumulated as a cause for enlightenment. I rejoice in the definite liberation of embodied beings from the suffering of samsara.
English 2: I rejoice in the accumulation of virtue that becomes the cause of enlightenment. I rejoice in the certain liberation of embodied beings from the sufferings of samsara.

Sanskrit: सर्वासु दिक्षु संबुद्धान् प्रार्थयामि कृताञ्जलिः। धर्मप्रदीपं कुर्वन्तु मोहाद्दुःखप्रपातिनाम्॥४॥
English 1: With my palms joined, I implore the buddhas in all directions: Light the lamp of dharma in the gloom of suffering beings' confusion!
English 2: To all the Buddhas in every direction, I join my palms and pray: For sentient beings confused in the darkness of suffering, Please kindle the lamp of Dharma.

Sanskrit: एवं सर्वमिदं कृत्वा यन्मयासादितं शुभम्। तेन स्यां सर्वसत्त्वानां सर्वदुःखप्रशान्तिकृत्॥६॥
English 1: May the virtue I have amassed by doing all of this eliminate all the suffering of every sentient being.
English 2: Having done all these things, by whatever virtue I have accumulated, may it remove all the sufferings of all sentient beings.

Sanskrit: क्षुत्पिपासाव्यथां हन्यामन्नपानप्रवर्षणैः। दुर्भिक्षान्तरकल्पेषु भवेयं पानभोजनम्॥८॥
English 1: May showers of food and drink relieve the torments of hunger and thirst. In intermediate aeons of famine, may I become food and drink.
English 2: I shall cause a rain of food and drink to fall, removing the suffering of hunger and thirst. During the intermediate age of famine, I shall become food and drink.

Sanskrit: यदा कुशलयोग्योऽपि कुशलं न करोम्यहम्। अपायदुःखैः संमूढः किं करिष्याम्यहं तदा॥१८॥
English 1: If I do not act virtuously despite my fortune to do good, what will I do when stupefied by the suffering of the lower realms?
English 2: When I have the fortune to practice virtue, if I do not perform virtuous deeds, what can I do when I am confused by the sufferings of the lower realms?

Sanskrit: अकारणेनैव रिपुक्षतानि गात्रेष्वलंकारवदुद्वहन्ति। महार्थसिद्ध्यै तु समुद्यतस्य दुःखानि कस्मान्मम बाधकानि॥३९॥
English 1: If someone wounded pointlessly by enemies will flaunt their scars as decorations on their body, how then is suffering a cause of injury for me who truly strives to accomplish a great purpose?
English 2: When even wounds inflicted by a meaningless enemy are worn like ornaments on the body, why should suffering harm me when I strive correctly for a great purpose?

Sanskrit: यस्माद्भयानि सर्वाणि दुःखान्यप्रमितानि च। चित्तादेव भवन्तीति कथितं तत्त्ववादिना॥६॥
English 1: For he who spoke the truth has taught That everything we fear And sufferings beyond all measure Originate from mind.
English 2: Thus, all fears and immeasurable sufferings arise from the mind, as taught by the perfect speech itself.
Commentary 2: གཉིས་པ་ནི། འདི་ལྟར་འཇིགས་པ་ཐམས་ཅད་དང་འདི་ཕྱིའི་སྡུག་བསྔལ་དཔག་ཏུ་མེད་པ་ཡང་རང་གི་སེམས་ཕྱིན་ཅི་ལོག་པ་ལས་བྱུང་བ་ཡིན་ནོ་ཞེས་ཡང་དག་གསུང་བ་ཉིད་ཀྱིས་གསུངས་ཏེ། དཀོན་མཆོག་སྤྲིན་ལས། སེམས་ཉིད་དབང་དུ་གྱུར་ན་ཆོས་ཐམས་ཅད་དབང་དུ་འགྱུར་རོ། །ཞེས་པ་དང་། དགེ་བའམ་འོན་ཏེ་མི་དགེ་བའི། །ལས་ནི་སེམས་ཀྱིས་བསགས་པ་ཡིན། །ཞེས་པ་དང་། ཆོས་ཡང་དག་པར་སྡུད་པ་ལས། ཆོས་ཐམས་ཅད་ཀྱང་སེམས་ལ་རག་ལས་པ་ཡིན། ཞེས་གསུངས་སོ།

Sanskrit: दुःखं हन्तुं सुखं प्राप्तुं ते भ्रमन्ति मुधाम्बरे। यैरेतद्धर्मसर्वस्वं चित्तं गुह्यं न भावितम्॥१७॥
English 1: Those who don't know this secret of mind— The sublime, paramount of dharmas— Want to gain joy and end suffering But wander to no avail.
English 2: Those who do not know this secret of the mind, the supreme essence of the Dharma, though they desire to attain happiness and overcome suffering, they wander aimlessly without purpose.

Sanskrit: व्रणदुःखलवाद्भीतो रक्षामि व्रणमादरात्। संघातपर्वताघाताद्भीतश्चित्तव्रणं न किम्॥२०॥
English 1: If you are careful of a wound from fear of its slight, minor pain, why not protect the wound of mind from fear of crushing mountains?
English 2: If one is frightened by the small suffering of a wound and takes care of the wound, why not protect against the fears of being crushed and destroyed, which are like wounds of the mind?

Sanskrit: सातत्याभिनिवेशोत्थं प्रतिपक्षोत्थमेव च। गुणोपकारिक्षेत्रे च दुःखिते च महच्छुभम्॥८१॥
English 1: Inspired continuously by yearning or by the antidotes, great virtues are found in the fields of qualities, of benefit, and of suffering.
English 2: Constantly aroused by attachment or by its antidote, virtuous and beneficial, great virtue arises in suffering.
Commentary 2: དང་པོ་ལ་གསུམ་སྟེ། བསྒྲུབ་བྱ་དགེ་བ་སྟོབས་ལྡན་བསྟན་པ་དང་། སྒྲུབ་ཚུལ་དང་། མཆོག་དམན་གྱི་བླང་དོར་བསྟན་པའོ། །དང་པོ་ནི། དུས་རྟག་པར་ཏེ་རྒྱུན་ལྡན་དང་། བསམ་པ་མངོན་ཞེན་ཏེ་འདུན་པ་དྲག་པོ་དང་། དེའི་མི་མཐུན་ཕྱོགས་འཇོམས་ནུས་ཀྱི་གཉེན་པོ་ཡིས་ནི་བསླངས་བ་ཉིད་དང་། ཡུལ་ཡོན་ཏན་གྱི་ཞིང་སངས་རྒྱས་སོགས་དང་། ཕན་འདོགས་པའི་ཞིང་ཕ་མ་ལ་སོགས་པ་དང་། སྡུག་བསྔལ་བའི་ཞིང་ནད་པ་ལ་སོགས་པ་ལ་བརྟེན་ནས་དགེ་བ་ཆེན་པོར་འགྱུར་ལ། མི་དགེ་བ་ཡང་དེ་དང་འདྲ་སྟེ། བཤེས་སྤྲིང་ལས། རྟག་ཏུ་མངོན་པར་ཞེན་དང་གཉེན་པོ་མེད། །ཡོན་ཏན་གཙོ་ལྡན་གཞི་ལས་བྱུང་བའི་ལས། །དགེ་དང་མི་དགེ་རྣམ་ལྔ་ཆེན་པོ་སྟེ། །དེ་བས་དགེ་བ་སྤྱོད་ལ་བརྩོན་པར་མཛོད། །ཅེས་གསུངས་སོ། །

Sanskrit: एवमादीनि दुःखानि करोतीत्यरिसंज्ञया। यः क्रोधं हन्ति निर्बन्धात् स सुखीह परत्र च॥ ६॥
English 1: The enemy anger will create sufferings such as these. Those who diligently overcome anger are happy here and elsewhere.
English 2: The enemy of anger and the like cause suffering. One who diligently overcomes anger will be happy here and elsewhere.

Sanskrit: दुःखं न्यक्कारपारुष्यमयशश्चेत्यनीप्सितम्। प्रियाणामात्मनो वापि शत्रोश्चैतद्विपर्ययात्॥ ११॥
English 1: We don't want pain, humiliation, harsh words, or disrepute either for ourselves or for our friends. It's the opposite for our foes.
English 2: For myself or my friends, I do not desire suffering, contempt, harsh words, or unpleasant speech. For enemies, it is the opposite of this.
Commentary 2: རྒྱས་བཤད་ལ་གཉིས་ཏེ། ཁྲོ་བའི་ཡུལ་གྱི་དབྱེ་བ་སྤྱིར་བསྟན་པ་དང་། དེ་ལ་ཁྲོ་བ་དགག་པའོ། །དང་པོ་ནི། བདག་གམ་བདག་གི་བཤེས་རྣམས་ལ་སྡུག་བསྔལ་དང་། བརྙས་པ་སྟེ་མ་རྙེད་པ་དང་། ཚིག་རྩུབ་ཀྱིས་སྨད་པ་དང་། གྲགས་མིན་བརྗོད་པའི་མི་སྙན་པ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ་བཞི་པ་མི་འདོད་ཅིང་། བཟློག་པ་བཞི་པོ་འདོད་དེ་དགྲ་ལ་དེ་ལས་བཟློག་པས་ན། སྡུག་བསྔལ་སོགས་འདོད་ལ་བདེ་བ་ལ་སོགས་མི་འདོད་པ་བཅུ་གཉིས་བྱས་པ་དང་། འདོད་པ་བཅུ་གཉིས་ཀྱི་གེགས་བྱས་པ་ལས་ཁྲོ་བ་འབྱུང་བ་ཡིན་ནོ། །

Sanskrit: कथंचिल्लभ्यते सौख्यं दुःखं स्थितमयत्नतः। दुःखेनैव च निःसारः चेतस्तस्माद् दृढीभव॥ १२॥
English 1: The causes of happiness are rare; The causes of pain are frequent. Without pain, there's no wish for freedom, So, mind, you must be steadfast.
English 2: The causes of happiness arise occasionally. The causes of suffering are very many. Without suffering, there is no definite liberation. Therefore, mind, resolve to be steadfast.
Commentary 2: གཉིས་པ་ལ་གཉིས་ཏེ། མི་འདོད་པ་བྱེད་པ་དང་། འདོད་པའི་གེགས་བྱས་པ་ལ་ཁྲོ་བ་དགག་པའོ། །དང་པོ་ལ་གསུམ་སྟེ། བདག་ལ་ཉེས་པ་བཞི་བྱེད་པ་དང་། བཤེས་ལ་ཉེས་པ་བཞི་བྱེད་པ་དང་། དགྲ་ལ་ལེགས་པ་བཞི་བྱེད་པ་ལ་ཁྲོ་བ་དགག་པའོ། །དང་པོ་ལ་གཉིས་ཏེ། བདག་ལ་སྡུག་བསྔལ་བྱེད་པ་དང་། བརྙས་སོགས་གསུམ་བྱེད་པ་ལ་ཁྲོ་བ་དགག་པའོ། ། དང་པོ་ལ་གསུམ་སྟེ། སྡུག་བསྔལ་དང་ལེན་དང་། ཆོས་ལ་ངེས་པར་སེམས་པ་དང་། གནོད་པ་ལ་ཇི་མི་སྙམ་པའི་བཟོད་པའོ། །དང་པོ་ལ་བཞི་སྟེ། འཁོར་བའི་རང་བཞིན་དུ་དང་། ངེས་འབྱུང་གི་རྒྱུར་དང་། གོམས་པས་བཟོད་པ་བརྟགས་པ་དང་། ཡོན་ཏན་གྱི་རྣམ་པར་ཡིད་ལ་བྱ་བའོ། །དང་པོ་ནི། འཁོར་བ་ན་བདེ་བའི་རྒྱུ་དགེ་བ་ལ་སོགས་པ་རེས་འགའ་ཙམ་འབྱུང་སྟེ་དཀོན་ལ། སྡུག་བསྔལ་གྱི་རྒྱུ་མི་དགེ་བ་ལ་སོགས་པ་ནི་ཤིན་ཏུ་མང་པོ་འབད་མེད་དུ་ཡོད་པས་སྡུག་བསྔལ་འབྱུང་བ་ནི་འཁོར་བའི་རང་བཞིན་ཡིན་པས་བཟོད་པར་བྱའོ། །

Sanskrit: उद्दंशदंशमशकक्षुत्पिपासादिवेदनाम्। महत्कण्ड्वादिदुःखं च किमनर्थं न पश्यसि॥ १५॥
English 1: Don't I see this with pointless pains Of serpents and mosquitoes, Of feelings of hunger, thirst, and such, And rashes and so forth?
English 2: Why do you not see the pointless suffering caused by snakes, mosquitoes, hunger, thirst, itching, and other such sensations?

Sanskrit: दुःखेऽपि नैव चित्तस्य प्रसादं क्षोभयेद् बुधः। संग्रामो हि सह क्लेशैर्युद्धे च सुलभा व्यथा॥ १९॥
English 1: Though pain occurs, the wise do not disturb their joy of mind. When waging war against afflictions, harm's plentiful in battle.
English 2: Even when suffering arises, the wise do not disturb their minds. When battling afflictions, many harms occur during the fight.

Sanskrit: उरसारातिघातान् ये प्रतीच्छन्तो जयन्त्यरीन्। ते ते विजयिनः शूराः शेषास्तु मृतमारकाः॥ २०॥
English 1: Triumphant heroes are they who ignore all pain and quash hatred and such—the enemy. Everyone else kills corpses.
English 2: Those who endure all sufferings and conquer enemies like anger are victorious heroes. The rest are killing corpses.

Sanskrit: गुणोऽपरश्च दुःखस्य यत्संवेगान्मदच्युतिः। संसारिषु च कारुण्यं पापाद्भीतिर्जिने स्पृहा॥ २१॥
English 1: Plus, suffering has benefits: Weariness dispels arrogance; Compassion arises for the samsaric; Shunning misdeeds, you delight in virtue.
English 2: Furthermore, the qualities of suffering are: It removes arrogance through weariness, generates compassion for those in samsara, makes one cautious of wrongdoing and delights in virtue.

Sanskrit: पित्तादिषु न मे कोपो महादुःखकरेष्वपि। सचेतनेषु किं कोपः तेऽपि प्रत्ययकोपिताः॥ २२॥
English 1: We don't get angry at bile and such, great sources of suffering. So why be angry at the sentient? They too are all provoked by conditions.
English 2: Why not be angry at great sources of suffering like bile and so on? Why be angry at those with minds? All of these are provoked by conditions.
Commentary 2: གཉིས་པ་ལ་གསུམ་སྟེ། གནོད་བྱེད་ལ་ཁྲོ་བ་བཟློག་པ་དང་། དེ་ལ་མི་རིགས་པ་སྤོང་བ་དང་། སྐབས་དོན་བསྡུ་བའོ། །དང་པོ་ལ་གསུམ་སྟེ། གནོད་བྱེད་ལ་རང་དབང་མེད་པས་ཁྲོ་བའི་ཡུལ་དུ་མི་རིགས་པ་དང་། རང་དབང་ཡོད་པའི་གནོད་བྱེད་དགག་པ་དང་། དོན་བསྡུ་བའོ། །དང་པོ་ལ་གསུམ་སྟེ། རང་དབང་དང་། སེམས་པ་མེད་པ་དང་། དོན་བསྡུ་བའོ། ། དང་པོ་ནི། དགྲས་བདག་ལ་སྡུག་བསྔལ་བསྐྱེད་པའི་ཕྱིར་དེ་ལ་ཁྲོའོ་སྙམ་ན། མཁྲིས་པ་དང་བད་ཀན་ལ་སོགས་སྡུག་བསྔལ་མང་པོའི་འབྱུང་གནས་ཆེན་པོ་ལའང་མི་ཁྲོ་བར་སེམས་ཡོད་ཀྱི་དགྲ་བོ་ཁོ་ན་ལ་ཅི་སྟེ་ཁྲོ། མཁྲིས་སོགས་རྐྱེན་གྱིས་རང་དབང་མེད་པར་བྱུང་བས་མི་ཁྲོའོ་སྙམ་ན། གནོད་བྱེད་དེ་དག་ཀུན་ཀྱང་ཉོན་མོངས་པའི་རྐྱེན་གྱིས་སྡུག་བསྔལ་ཞིང་རྐྱེན་ཉོན་མོངས་པ་དེ་ཡང་མི་འདོད་བཞིན་དུ་རྐྱེན་གྱི་སྟོབས་ཀྱིས་ནན་གྱིས་འབྱུང་བར་འགྱུར་ཏེ།

Sanskrit: वारणापि न युक्तैवं कः किं वारयतीति चेत्। युक्ता प्रतीत्यता यस्माद्दुःखस्योपरतिर्मता॥ ३२॥
English 1: Who averts what? Even averting would be illogical. It's logical to say suffering will cease, dependent on that.
English 2: If one asks what should be prevented by what, and whether prevention is reasonable, it is not unreasonable to desire that sufferings be cut off by relying on that.

Sanskrit: यदि तु स्वेच्छया सिद्धिः सर्वेषामेव देहिनाम्। न भवेत्कस्यचिद्दुःखं न दुःखं कश्चिदिच्छति॥ ३४॥
English 1: If things were accomplished by free will, no one would ever have any suffering, for no living being wants to suffer.
English 2: If things were achieved by one's own wish, since no one desires suffering, no embodied being would ever experience suffering.

Sanskrit: तच्छस्त्रं मम कायश्च द्वयं दुःखस्य कारणम्। तेन शस्त्रं मया कायो गृहीतः कुत्र कुप्यते॥ ४३॥
English 1: Their weapons and my body both are causes of suffering. They wield the weapons, I the body. With whom should I get angry?
English 2: His weapon and my body are both causes of suffering. He drew the weapon, I put forth the body. At which should I be angry?

Sanskrit: गण्डोऽयं प्रतिमाकारो गृहीतो घट्टनासहः। तृष्णान्धेन मया तत्र व्यथायां कुत्र कुप्यते॥ ४४॥
English 1: Blinded by craving, I have grasped this human body-like blister that, prone to pain, can't bear being touched. Whom to get mad at when it's hurt?
English 2: When I, blinded by craving, grasp at a human-like form that is unbearable to touch and full of suffering, at whom should I be angry for the harm that results?

Sanskrit: दुःखं नेच्छामि दुःखस्य हेतुमिच्छामि बालिशः। स्वापराधागते दुःखे कस्मादन्यत्र कुप्यते॥ ४५॥
English 1: The childish don't want suffering, but thirst for suffering's causes. When harmed by my own wrongs, what reason is there to resent others?
English 2: Children do not want suffering, yet they crave the causes of suffering. When harmed by their own faults, what reason is there to blame others?

Sanskrit: मनो हन्तुममूर्तत्वान्न शक्यं केनचित्क्वचित्। शरीराभिनिवेशात्तु चित्तं दुःखेन बाध्यते॥५२॥
English 1: Because the mind's not physical, No one can wound it at all. Because of fixation on the body, The body is harmed by pain.
English 2: The mind is not physical, so no one can destroy it anywhere. Due to strong attachment to the body, the body is harmed by sufferings.

Sanskrit: वरमद्यैव मे मृत्युर्न मिथ्याजीवितं चिरम्। यस्माच्चिरमपि स्थित्वा मृत्युदुःखं तदेव मे॥ ५६॥
English 1: It's better I die now than live long with wrong livelihood. Even were I to live for long, the pain of death's the same.
English 2: It is better for me to die today than to live long through wrong livelihood. Even if I were to live long, it would still end in the suffering of death.

Sanskrit: मारणीयः करं छित्त्वा मुक्तश्चेत्किमभद्रकम्। मनुष्यदुःखैर्नरकान्मुक्तश्चेत्किमभद्रकम्॥ ७२॥
English 1: What's wrong if someone condemned to death, Their hand cut off, is freed? What's wrong with human suffering Removing you from the hells?
English 2: If a person condemned to death escapes by having their hand cut off, isn't that good? If one can be freed from hell through human suffering, isn't that good?

Sanskrit: यद्येतन्मात्रमेवाद्य दुःखं सोढुं न पार्यते। तन्नारकव्यथाहेतुः क्रोधः कस्मान्न वार्यते॥ ७३॥
English 1: If I cannot bear this amount of suffering in the present, why then do I not stop my anger, cause of hell's agonies?
English 2: If I cannot endure even this much present suffering, why then do I not turn away from anger, the cause of hellish suffering?

Sanskrit: न चेदं तादृशं दुःखं महार्थं च करिष्यति। जगद्दुःखहरे दुःखे प्रीतिरेवात्र युज्यते॥ ७५॥
English 1: But this is not that great a harm, And a great aim will be accomplished. It's right to only be delighted At pains that dispel harm to beings.
English 2: This is not so harmful, and great purposes will be accomplished. Therefore, it is right to take joy here solely in removing the harm and suffering of beings.

Sanskrit: अथ त्वदिच्छया सिद्धं तद्दुःखे किं सुखं तव। अथाप्यर्थो भवेदेवमनर्थः को न्वतः परः॥ ८८॥
English 1: How would it please you to accomplish the pain you wish for them? You say you would be satisfied— What greater ruin than that?
English 2: Your desires bring suffering. Even if fulfilled, what joy is there for you? If you become satisfied, what could be more ruinous than that?

Sanskrit: दुःखं प्रवेष्टुकामस्य ये कपाटत्वमागताः। बुद्धाधिष्ठानत इव द्वेषस्तेषु कथं मम॥ १०१॥
English 1: When I want to rush into suffering, How is it I get angry At those who, as if blessed by the Buddha, Don't let me, blocking the way?
English 2: I desire to enter into suffering. As if blessed by the Buddha, it has become an unopened door. How can I be angry at that?

Sanskrit: अव्यापारसुखास्वादनिद्रापाश्रयतृष्णया। संसारदुःखानुद्वेगादालस्यमुपजायते॥३॥
English 1: Laziness arises from not wearying of samsaric pain, from craving sleep and savoring the pleasures of being indolent.
English 2: Because of tasting the pleasure of laziness and desire for sleep, one does not tire of the sufferings of samsara. Thus, laziness arises.
Commentary 2: གཉིས་པ་དེ་སྤོང་ཚུལ་ལ་གསུམ་སྟེ། སྦྱོར་བ་མེད་པ་དང་། བྱ་བ་ངན་པ་ལ་ཞེན་པ་དང་། སྒྱིད་ལུག་པའི་ལེ་ལོ་སྤོང་བའོ། དང་པོ་ལ་གཉིས་ཏེ། རྒྱུ་ངོས་བཟུང་བ་དང་། དེ་སྤོང་བའོ། །དང་པོ་ནི། སྙོམ་ལས་ཏེ་དགེ་བ་ལ་མི་བརྩོན་པར་ཡིད་དལ་དུ་གནས་པའི་བདེ་བའི་རོ་མྱང་བ་སྟེ་དེ་ལ་ཞེན་པ་དང་། གཉིད་ལ་བརྟེན་པ་ལ་ལྷག་པར་ཆགས་པའི་སྲེད་པ་ཡིས་འཁོར་བའི་སྡུག་བསྔལ་ལ་མི་སྐྱོ་བ་ལས་ལེ་ལོ་ཉེ་བར་སྐྱེ་བར་འགྱུར་རོ་ཞེས་པའམ། འགྲེལ་ཆེན་ལས་འཁོར་བའི་སྡུག་བསྔལ་ལ་མི་སྐྱོ་བ་ལས་སྙོམ་ལས་ཀྱི་བདེ་བའི་རོ་མྱང་བ་དང་། དེ་ལས་གཉིད་ལ་སྲེད་པ་འབྱུང་ཞེས་འབྱུང་ངོ་། །

Sanskrit: जीवमत्स्य इवास्मीति युक्तं भयमिहैव ते। किं पुनः कृतपापस्य तीव्रान्नरकदुःखतः॥११॥
English 1: If like a living, writhing fish, you have such terror in this life, what of the intense suffering of hell from the misdeeds you've done?
English 2: If you are fearful in this life, like a live fish writhing on the ground, what need is there to speak of the unbearable sufferings of hell that result from evil deeds?

Sanskrit: निरुद्यम फलाकाङ्क्षिन् सुकुमार बहुव्यथ। मृत्युग्रस्तोऽमराकार हा दुःखित विहन्यसे॥१३॥
English 1: You want results without any effort— Such pain for one so delicate! When grasped by death, you're like a god. Alas! Suffering will destroy you!
English 2: Those who desire results without effort, and the fickle-minded suffer much harm. Though appearing godlike, they are seized by death. Alas! They are destroyed by sufferings.

Sanskrit: मानुष्यं नावमासाद्य तर दुःखमहानदीम्। मूढ कालो न निद्राया इयं नौर्दुर्लभा पुनः॥१४॥
English 1: Free yourself with the human boat from the great river of suffering. Such a boat is hard to get again. Now is no time for sleep, you fool.
English 2: Relying on the boat of human birth, cross over the great river of suffering. This boat is hard to find later, so foolish ones, do not sleep when the time has come.

Sanskrit: मुक्त्वा धर्मरतिं श्रेष्ठामनन्तरतिसंततिम्। रतिरौद्धत्यहास्यादौ दुःखहेतौ कथं तव॥१५॥
English 1: Forsaking the sublime joy of dharma, the cause of infinite delight, why do you relish such distractions and games that will cause suffering?
English 2: Having abandoned the supreme joy of the holy Dharma, which is the source of limitless joy, why do you delight in distractions and frivolity, which are causes of suffering?

Sanskrit: इदं तु मे परिमितं दुःखं संबोधिसाधनम्। नष्टशल्यव्यथापोहे तदुत्पादनदुःखवत्॥२२॥
English 1: The suffering for me to achieve Enlightenment, though, has a limit, Like pain from an incision made To excise a painful foreign object.
English 2: The suffering I experience in striving for enlightenment is limited. It is like the pain of incising the body to remove an internal ailment.

Sanskrit: न दुःखी त्यक्तपापत्वात्पण्डितत्वान्न दुर्मनाः। मिथ्याकल्पनया चित्ते पापात्काये यतो व्यथा॥२७॥
English 1: There is no pain from giving up wrong, No melancholy from being wise. For misconceptions and misdeeds Harm the mind and body.
English 2: There is no suffering for the sake of abandoning evil. There is no unhappiness for the sake of wisdom. Thus, wrong views and evil harm the mind and body.

Sanskrit: छन्दस्थामरतिमुक्तिबलं सत्त्वार्थसिद्धये। छन्दं दुःखभयात्कुर्यादनुशंसांश्च भावयन्॥३१॥
English 1: To benefit beings, the forces are longing, steadfastness, joy, and deferring. Longing is born of fearing suffering and contemplating its benefits.
English 2: To accomplish the welfare of sentient beings, the forces are faith, steadfastness, joy, and renunciation. Faith is generated by contemplating suffering, fear, and the benefits of that.
Commentary 1: དེ་བསྟན་པར་བྱ་བའི་ཕྱིར། སེམས་ཅན་དོན་ཞེས་སྨོས་ཏེ། གྲུབ་བྱ་ན་སྟེ། གྲུབ་པར་བྱ་བའི་དོན་ཏོ། །མོས་པ་ནི་དགེ་བ་ལ་སྤྲོ་བའོ། །བརྟན་པ་ནི་བརྩམས་པ་མཐར་ཕྱིན་པའོ། །དགའ་བ་ནི་དམ་པའི་ལས་ལ་ཞེན་པའོ། །དོར་བ་ནི་ནམ་མི་ནུས་པའི་སྐབས་སུ་གཏོང་ཞིང་ཀློད་པའོ། །དེ་ལ་མོས་པའི་སྐྱེ་བའི་རྒྱུ་བསྟན་པའི་ཕྱིར། མོས་པ་ཞེས་སྨོས་ཏེ། སྡུག་བསྔལ་ནི་དམྱལ་བ་ལ་སོགས་པའོ། །དགེ་བའི་ཕན་ཡོན་ནི་བདེ་གཤེགས་སུ་སྐྱེ་བ་ལ་སོགས་པའོ། །བསམ་པ་ཞེས་པ་ནི་ཡང་ནས་ཡང་དུ་བསམ་པས་སོ། །
Commentary 2: གསུམ་པ་ལ་བསྟན་བཤད་གཉིས་ལས། དང་པོ་ནི། སེམས་ཅན་གྱི་དོན་བསྒྲུབ་པར་བྱ་བའི་ཕྱིར་སྤང་བྱའི་དགྲ་འཇོམས་པའི་དཔུང་གི་མོས་པ་ཞེས་བྱུང་ཡང་། འགྲེལ་ཆེན་ལས། འདུན་པ་ནི་འདིར་དགེ་བ་འདོད་པ་ཡིན་ལ་ཞེས་བྱུང་ཞིང་། བླ་མ་དཔང་ལོ་ཙཱ་བ་འདི་རྣམས་རྒྱ་དཔེ་ལ་འདུན་པར་ཡོད་གསུངས་པས། སྐབས་འདིར་ནི་མོས་པ་ཞེས་པ་ཐམས་ཅད་འདུན་པར་ཤེས་པར་བྱའོ། ། འདིར་ཡང་དགེ་བ་ལ་འདུན་པ་དང་། དེ་བརྩམས་པ་ལས་མི་ལྡོག་པའི་བརྟན་པ་དང་། དེ་ལས་ལྷག་པར་དགའ་བ་དང་། དོར་ན་དགོས་པ་ཆེ་བའི་སྐབས་སུ་དོར་བ་རྣམས་ཡིན་ལ། དེ་ཡང་མོས་པ་ནི་མི་དགེ་བའི་འབྲས་བུ་སྡུག་བསྔལ་གྱིས་འཇིགས་པ་དེ་དང་མོས་པ་དེའི་ཕན་ཡོན་བསམས་པས་བསྐྱེད་དོ། །

Sanskrit: तत्र दोषक्षयारम्भे लेशोऽपि मम नेक्ष्यते। अप्रमेयव्यथाभाज्ये नोरः स्फुटति मे कथम्॥३४॥
English 1: And I don't see that I've begun to exhaust them even the slightest bit. Infinite suffering is my lot; Why does my heart not burst apart?
English 2: When not even a fraction of the effort to exhaust negativities is seen in me, why does my heart not break, as I am a source of immeasurable suffering?

Sanskrit: भीतेभ्यो नाभयं दत्तमार्ता न सुखिनः कृताः। दुःखाय केवलं मातुर्गतोऽस्मि गर्भशल्यताम्॥३८॥
English 1: If I have not provided safety to those in fear, or given comfort to the wretched, I have only created suffering and pain inside my mother's womb.
English 2: If I do not give fearlessness to the fearful and happiness to the miserable, I will only produce the pain and suffering of a mother's womb.

Sanskrit: दुःखानि दौर्मनस्यानि भयानि विविधानि च। अभिलाषविघाताश्च जायन्ते पापकारिणाम्॥४१॥
English 1: Sufferings, unhappiness, dangers of assorted types, and deprivation of desires occur because of committing misdeeds.
English 2: Suffering, unhappiness, various kinds of fears, and separation from desires arise from engaging in sinful actions.
Commentary 2: གསུམ་པ་ལ་བསྟན་བཤད་བསྡུ་གསུམ་ལས། དང་པོ་ནི། མོས་པ་དེ་ཇི་ལྟར་བསྐྱེད་པར་བྱ་ཞེ་ན། མོས་པ་དེའི་ཡང་རྩ་བ་རྟག་ཏུ་ནི་དགེ་སྡིག་གི་རྣམ་སྨིན་གྱི་འབྲས་བུ་སོ་སོར་མྱོང་བར་འགྱུར་རོ་སྙམ་དུ་བསྒོམས་པའོ། །གཉིས་པ་ལ་གཉིས་ཏེ། དཀར་ནག་གི་ལས་འབྲས་སྤྱིར་བསྟན་པ་དང་། དེ་དག་གི་ཁྱད་པར་གྱི་འབྲས་བུ་བཤད་པའོ། །དང་པོ་ནི། འབྲས་བུ་སྒོ་ལྔའི་འཁོར་གྱི་སྡུག་བསྔལ་དང་། ཡིད་ཤེས་ཀྱི་འཁོར་གྱི་ཡིད་མི་བདེ་བ་དང་། འཇིགས་པ་རྣམ་པ་སྣ་ཚོགས་པ་དང་། འདོད་པ་རྣམས་དང་བྲལ་བ་ནི་རྒྱུ་སྡིག་པ་སྤྱོད་པ་ལས་འབྱུང་བར་འགྱུར།

Sanskrit: पापकारिसुखेच्छा तु यत्र यत्रैव गच्छति। तत्र तत्रैव तत्पापैर्दुःखशस्त्रैर्विहन्यते॥४३॥
English 1: Wherever they go, those who commit misdeeds, though they want happiness, will be destroyed by the weapons of suffering because of their wrongs.
English 2: Though one desires happiness while committing evil, wherever one goes, that evil will thoroughly destroy one with the weapon of suffering.

Sanskrit: एक उत्पद्यते जन्तुर्म्रियते चैक एव हि। नान्यस्य तद्व्यथाभागः किं प्रियैर्विघ्नकारकैः॥३३॥
English 1: At birth, it's born alone; at death, it dies alone. If no one else can take a share of the pain, what good are loved ones who make hindrances?
English 2: When born, one is born alone; when dying, one dies alone. If one does not take on the suffering of others, what use are obstructing friends?

Sanskrit: दण्डयात्राभिरपरे प्रवासक्लेशदुःखिताः। वत्सररैपि नेक्षन्ते पुत्रदारांस्तदर्थिनः॥७४॥
English 1: Some go on long journeys, troubled and suffering from being far away. Though they wish to see their wives and children, they won't see them even for a whole year.
English 2: Some who travel far, afflicted with troubles and suffering from long journeys, though desiring to see their children and wives, may not see them even in their dreams.

Sanskrit: अर्जनरक्षणनाशविषादै-रर्थमनर्थमनन्तमवेहि। व्यग्रतया धनसक्तमतीनां नावसरो भवदुःखविमुक्तेः॥७९॥
English 1: Know the travails of getting, keeping, and losing it Make wealth a never-ending source of ill. For those whom greed for wealth distracts, there is no chance For freedom from the suffering of existence.
English 2: Through the torment of accumulating, guarding, and losing, know that wealth is an endless source of trouble. Those distracted by attachment to wealth have no chance of liberation from the sufferings of existence.

Sanskrit: ततः कोटिशतेनापि श्रमभागेन बुद्धता। चर्यादुःखान्महद्दुःखं सा च बोधिर्न कामिनाम्॥८३॥
English 1: For just a millionth fraction of the effort, one could attain Buddhahood. But those with desires, instead of practicing awakened conduct, have great sufferings and no awakening.
English 2: If Buddhahood can be achieved with just a fraction of that effort, those who desire enlightenment but engage in greater suffering will not attain enlightenment.

Sanskrit: न शस्त्रं न विषं नाग्निर्न प्रपातो न वैरिणः। कामानामुपमां यान्ति नरकादिव्यथास्मृतेः॥८४॥
English 1: Considering the sufferings of hell and so forth, there's no weapon, poison, fire, abyss, or foe that can compare to the desires.
English 2: When considering the sufferings of hell and such, weapons, poison, fire, precipices, and enemies cannot even serve as examples for the desires.

Sanskrit: विहृत्य यत्र क्वचिदिष्टकालं शून्यालये वृक्षतले गुहासु। परिग्रहरक्षणखेदमुक्तः चरत्यपेक्षाविरतो यथेष्टम्॥८७॥
English 1: In empty huts, by trees, or else in caves, You may remain as long as you desire. The pains of getting and keeping left behind, You live without a care, dependent on none.
English 2: In empty houses, at the foot of trees, or in caves, dwell as long as you wish. Free from the suffering of clinging and protecting possessions, live carefree without dependence.

Sanskrit: परात्मसमतामादौ भावयेदेवमादरात्। समदुःखसुखाः सर्वे पालनीया मयात्मवत्॥९०॥
English 1: First meditate ardently upon the equality of self and other. They're equal in both pain and pleasure, so protect everyone like yourself.
English 2: From the very beginning, strive to meditate on the equality of self and others. Since happiness and suffering are equal, protect all as you would yourself.
Commentary 2: གཉིས་པ་ཀུན་རྫོབ་བྱང་སེམས་སྒོམ་པ་ལ་གསུམ་སྟེ། བདག་གཞན་མཉམ་པ་དང་། བརྗེ་བ་དང་། ཐུན་མོང་གི་བྱ་བའོ། །དང་པོ་ལ་གསུམ་སྟེ། བདག་གཞན་མཉམ་པ་སྒོམ་པར་གདམས་པ་དང་། བསྒོམ་བྱ་རྒྱས་པར་བཤད་པ་དང་། དོན་བསྡུ་བའོ། །དང་པོ་ནི། ཀུན་རྫོབ་བྱང་ཆུབ་ཀྱི་སེམས་ལ་གཉིས་ཡོད་པ་ལས་བདག་དང་གཞན་དུ་མཉམ་པ་ནི་དང་པོ་ཉིད་དུ་འབད་དེ་བསྒོམ་པར་བྱ་སྟེ། དེ་མེད་ན་གཞན་ཕན་གྱི་སེམས་རྣམ་དག་མི་སྐྱེ་བས་སོ། །གཉིས་པ་ལ་གཉིས་ཏེ། དངོས་དང་། ཕན་ཡོན་ནོ། །དང་པོ་ལ་བསྟན་བཤད་བསྡུ་གསུམ་གྱི། དང་པོ་ནི། སེམས་ཅན་ཐམས་ཅད་ཆོས་ཅན། བདག་བཞིན་དུ་བསྲུང་བར་རིགས་ཏེ། བདེ་བ་འདོད་པ་དང་སྡུག་བསྔལ་མི་འདོད་པར་བདག་དང་མཉམ་པའི་ཕྱིར་རོ། །

Sanskrit: यद्यप्यन्येषु देहेषु मद्दुःखं न प्रबाधते। तथापि तद्दुःखमेव ममात्मस्नेहदुःसहम्॥९२॥
English 1: Even though my own suffering does not cause harm to others' bodies, my suffering is unbearable because of ego-clinging.
English 2: Even if my suffering does not harm others' bodies, still I cannot bear that suffering due to clinging to a self.

Sanskrit: मयान्यदुःखं हन्तव्यं दुःखत्वादात्मदुःखवत्। अनुग्राह्या मयान्येऽपि सत्त्वत्वादात्मसत्त्ववत्॥९४॥
English 1: I will dispel others' suffering since it is suffering, like my own. I shall bring benefit to others since they are beings, like my body.
English 2: I should remove others' suffering, for it is suffering just like my own. I should benefit others, for they are sentient beings just like my own body.
Commentary 2: གཉིས་པ་ལ་གཉིས་ཏེ། རྟགས་དགོས་པ་དང་། ཁྱབ་པ་སྒྲུབ་པའོ། །དང་པོ་ལ་གཉིས་ཏེ། ཡུལ་བདེ་སྡུག་དང་། ཡུལ་ཅན་འདོད་པ་མཚུངས་པའོ། །དང་པོ་ནི། གཞན་གྱི་སྡུག་བསྔལ་ཆོས་ཅན། བདག་གིས་བསལ་བྱ་ཡིན་ཏེ། སྡུག་བསྔལ་ཡིན་པའི་ཕྱིར། དཔེར་ན་བདག་གི་སྡུག་བསྔལ་བཞིན་ནོ། །སེམས་ཅན་གཞན་ཆོས་ཅན། དེས་བདག་གིས་ཕན་པར་བྱ་བ་ཡིན་ཏེ། སེམས་ཅན་ཡིན་པའི་ཕྱིར། བདག་གི་ལུས་བཞིན་ནོ། །

Sanskrit: यदा मम परेषां च भयं दुःखं च न प्रियम्। तदात्मनः को विशेषो यत्तं रक्षामि नेतरम्॥९६॥
English 1: When both I and others are the same in not wanting to suffer, and they're no different from me, then why protect myself and not others?
English 2: When both myself and others are similar in not wanting suffering, what difference is there between us? Why do I protect myself and not others?

Sanskrit: तद्दुःखेन न मे बाधेत्यतो यदि न रक्ष्यते। नागामिकायदुःखान्मे बाधा तत्केन रक्ष्यते॥९७॥
English 1: If their suffering does not harm me, why protect myself and not them? And if future suffering does not harm me, why guard against it?
English 2: If suffering does not harm me, why protect against it? And if future suffering does not harm, why guard against that?

Sanskrit: अस्वामिकानि दुःखानि सर्वाण्येवाविशेषतः। दुःखत्वादेव वार्याणि नियमस्तत्र किंकृतः॥१०२॥
English 1: The suffering has no owner. There is no difference for anyone. Since it is suffering, it should be dispelled. Why should there be any certainty about that?
English 2: Suffering has no owner; all are without distinction. Because it is suffering, it should be dispelled. What is to be done with certainty about that?

Sanskrit: दुःखं कस्मान्निवार्यं चेत्सर्वेषामविवादतः। वार्यं चेत्सर्वमप्येवं न चेदात्मापि सत्त्ववत्॥१०३॥
English 1: There's no dispute the suffering of everyone must be prevented. If mine's prevented, prevent all. Or else, like beings', not mine either.
English 2: Why should the suffering of all be dispelled? This is beyond dispute. If it is to be dispelled, then all should be dispelled. If not, I am just like other sentient beings.

Sanskrit: कृपया बहु दुःखं चेत्कस्मादुत्पद्यते बलात्। जगद्दुःखं निरूप्येदं कृपादुःखं कथं बहु॥१०४॥
English 1: Compassion is too painful, you say, "So why arouse it with such effort?" But when you think of beings' torments, How is the pain of compassion greater?
English 2: Why deliberately cultivate compassion that brings much suffering? When you consider the suffering of beings, how can compassion not bring much suffering?

Sanskrit: बहूनामेकदुःखेन यदि दुःखं विगच्छति। उत्पाद्यमेव तद्दुःखं सदयेन परात्मनोः॥१०५॥
English 1: If a single suffering eliminates many miseries, those with compassion will induce that suffering in themselves and others.
English 2: If by one suffering, many sufferings can be eliminated, then one with compassion should generate that suffering for oneself and others.

Sanskrit: अतः सुपुष्पचन्द्रेण जानतापि नृपापदम्। आत्मदुःखं न निहतं बहूनां दुःखिनां व्ययात्॥१०६॥
English 1: Thus even though Supushpachandra knew that the king would cause him harm, he did not remove his own suffering, in order to end the sufferings of many.
English 2: Therefore, although Chandraprabha knew of the king's harm, he did not remove his own suffering, for the sake of eliminating the suffering of many.

Sanskrit: ये केचिद्दुःखिता लोके सर्वे ते स्वसुखेच्छया। ये केचित्सुखिता लोके सर्वे तेऽन्यसुखेच्छया॥१२९॥
English 1: All happiness in the world is born of wishing others happiness. All suffering in the world is born of wanting happiness for yourself.
English 2: Whatever happiness there is in the world, all of it comes from desiring others to be happy. Whatever suffering there is in the world, all of it comes from desiring oneself to be happy.

Sanskrit: न नाम साध्यं बुद्धत्वं संसारेऽपि कुतः सुखम्। स्वसुखस्यान्यदुःखेन परिवर्तमकुर्वतः॥१३१॥
English 1: If you do not exchange your pleasures For other beings' miseries, You will not achieve buddhahood Or have any happiness in samsara.

Sanskrit: त्यक्त्वान्योन्यसुखोत्पादं दृष्टादृष्टसुखोत्सवम्। अन्योन्यदुःखनाद् घोरं दुःखं गृह्णन्ति मोहिताः॥१३३॥
English 1: Fools throw away the perfect pleasure of gaining seen and unseen joys, and, causing others misery, they take on terrible suffering.
English 2: Abandoning all happiness and prosperity, both seen and unseen, the ignorant take on unbearable suffering due to causing suffering to others.

Sanskrit: उपद्रवा ये च भवन्ति लोके यावन्ति दुःखानि भयानि चैव। सर्वाणि तान्यात्मपरिग्रहेण तत्किं ममानेन परिग्रहेण॥१३४॥
English 1: All of the violence in the world and all the fear and suffering arise from clinging to a self. What does that ogre do for me?
English 2: Whatever harm and fears there are in the world, and all the sufferings that exist, all arise from clinging to a self. What then can this great demon do to me?

Sanskrit: एष सत्क्रियते नाहं लाभी नाहमयं यथा। स्तूयतेऽहमहं निन्द्यो दुःखितोऽहमयं सुखी॥१४१॥
English 1: They are respected; I am not. I do not get as much as them. They're praised, while I am ridiculed, And they are happy, while I suffer.
English 2: This one is honored, I am not. This one I have not found. This one is praised, I am criticized. This one is happy, I am suffering.
Commentary 2: གཉིས་པ་ལ་གཉིས་ཏེ། སྒོམ་ཚུལ་དངོས་དང་། དེའི་འཐད་པའོ། །དང་པོ་ལ་གསུམ་སྟེ། ཕྲག་དོག་དང་། འགྲན་སེམས་དང་། ང་རྒྱལ་བསྒོམ་པའོ། །དང་པོ་ལ་གཉིས་ལས། དང་པོ་འཇིག་རྟེན་གྱི་ཆོས་ལ་ཕྲག་དོག་བྱ་བ་ནི། བྱང་སེམས་འདི་ནི་འཇིག་རྟེན་གྱིས་བཀུར་བྱས་སེམས་ཅན་བདག་ནི་མིན། འདི་བཞིན་བདག་གིས་མི་རྙེད་ཅིང་འདི་ནི་བསྟོད་བྱས་བདག་ལ་སྨད་འདི་བདེ་བདག་ནི་སྡུག་བསྔལ་ལ།

Sanskrit: अप्रमेया गताः कल्पाः स्वार्थं जिज्ञासतस्तव। श्रमेण महतानेन दुःखमेव त्वयार्जितम्॥१५५॥
English 1: O mind, you have spent countless aeons wanting to benefit yourself, but even with such great ordeals, you've only created suffering.

Sanskrit: शरीरपक्षपातेन वृथा दुःखमुपार्ज्यते। किमस्य काष्ठतुल्यस्य द्वेषेणानुनयेन वा॥१८०॥
English 1: Because of doting on this body, I've brought myself pointless miseries. What use is getting attached or angry For this, which is the same as wood?

Sanskrit: यथा दृष्टं श्रुतं ज्ञातं नैवेह प्रतिषिध्यते। सत्यतः कल्पना त्वत्र दुःखहेतुर्निवार्यते॥२६॥
English 1: How things are seen or heard or known Is not what is rebutted here. Here it's the cause of suffering— The thought they're true—that is refuted.

Sanskrit: सक्तित्रासात्त्वनिर्मुक्त्या संसारे सिध्यति स्थितिः। मोहेन दुःखिनामर्थे शून्यताया इदं फलम्॥५३॥
English 1: Freed from extremes of greed and fear, To stay in samsara for the sake Of those who suffer due to delusion Is the result of emptiness.

Sanskrit: यद्दुःखजननं वस्तु त्रासस्तस्मात्प्रजायताम्। शून्यता दुःखशमनी ततः किं जायते भयम्॥५६॥
English 1: If fearfulness is born out of the things that produce suffering, then why is it that emptiness, the cure for suffering, provokes dread?

Sanskrit: कार्यं कस्य न चेत्सत्त्वः सत्यमीहा तु मोहतः। दुःखव्युपशमार्थं तु कार्यमोहो न वार्यते॥७७॥
English 1: Whose is the fruit if there are no beings? That's true; the wish is from delusion. For the sake of quelling suffering, Don't block delusion about the result.

Sanskrit: दुःखहेतुरहंकार आत्ममोहात्तु वर्धते। ततोऽपि न निवर्त्यश्चेत् वरं नैरात्म्यभावना॥७८॥
English 1: The cause of suffering—the ego—increases due to delusion about self. "But there's no stopping that," you say. To cultivate selflessness is supreme.

Sanskrit: अस्ति सूक्ष्मतया दुःखं स्थौल्यं तस्य हृतं ननु। तुष्टिमात्रापरा चेत्स्यात्तस्मात् साप्यस्य सूक्ष्मता॥९१॥
English 1: The pain is there in a subtle form. Has its gross form not been dispelled? If it's a different, mere pleasure, The subtle form would be of that.

Sanskrit: विरुद्धप्रत्ययोत्पत्तौ दुःखस्यानुदयो यदि। कल्पनाभिनिवेशो हि वेदनेत्यागतं ननु॥९२॥
English 1: If causes of its contrary arise, so pain does not occur, does that not prove that to conceive of it as feeling is just fixation?

Sanskrit: कुतः सुखं वा दुःखं वा किं प्रियं वा किमप्रियम्। का तृष्णा कुत्र सा तृष्णा मृग्यमाणा स्वभावतः॥१५३॥
English 1: Whence do pleasure and suffering come? What's to dislike and what's to like? When you investigate, in suchness, Who's there that craves? What's there to crave?

Sanskrit: मृताः पतन्त्यपायेषु दीर्घतीव्रव्यथेषु च। आगत्यागत्य सुगतिं भूत्वा भूत्वा सुखोचिताः॥१५७॥
English 1: Returning, returning to higher realms, Consuming, consuming the many pleasures, They die and plunge to lower realms— Intense, long-lasting agonies.

Sanskrit: अहो बतातिशोच्यत्वमेषां दुःखौघवर्तिनाम्। ये नेक्षन्ते स्वदौःस्थित्यमेवमप्यतिदुःस्थिताः॥१६४॥
English 1: Although the suffering is extreme, they do not see their own misery. Alas! It is most fitting to grieve for those deluged by suffering!

Sanskrit: स्नात्वा स्नात्वा यथा कश्चिद्विशेद्वह्निं मुहुर्मुहुः। स्वसौस्थित्यं च मन्यन्ते एवमप्यतिदुःस्थिताः॥१६५॥
English 1: Just as some bathe repeatedly but enter flames again and again, although they suffer terribly, they have the conceit that they are happy.

Sanskrit: एवं दुःखाग्नितप्तानां शान्तिं कुर्यामहं कदा। पुण्यमेघसमुद्भूतैः सुखोपकरणैः स्वकैः॥१६७॥
English 1: So when will I bring peace to those ravaged by fires of suffering by showering down from clouds of merit a rain of comforts to sustain them?

Sanskrit: सर्वासु दिक्षु यावन्तः कायचित्तव्यथातुराः। ते प्राप्नुवन्तु मत्पुण्यैः सुखप्रामोद्यसागरान्॥२॥
English 1: May everyone in all directions who's anguished or diseased in body or mind gain, through my merit, an ocean of happiness.

Sanskrit: आयातायात शीघ्रं भयमपनयत भ्रातरो जीविताः स्मः संप्राप्तोऽस्माकमेष ज्वलदभयकरः कोऽपि चीरीकुमारः। सर्वं यस्यानुभावाद्व्यसनमपगतं प्रीतिवेगाः प्रवृत्ताः जातं संबोधिचित्तं सकलजनपरित्राणमाता दया च॥१३॥
English 1: Friends, cast away your fear and hurry here! Who could this be, now come to us Relieving all our suffering, exuding the energy of joy, Protecting beings from all, the bodhisattva who has roused compassion, The youth with hair in a topknot who dispels our every fear?

Sanskrit: आकाशस्य स्थितिर्यावद्यावच्च जगतः स्थितिः। तावन्मम स्थितिर्भूयाज्जगद्दुःखानि निघ्नतः॥५५॥
English 1: Whatever the sufferings of wanderers, May they all ripen on me. May the sangha of bodhisattvas bring Beings to happiness.

Sanskrit: यत्किंचिज्जगतो दुःखं तत्सर्वं मयि पच्यताम्। बोधिसत्त्वशुभैः सर्वैर्जगत्सुखितमस्तु च॥५६॥
English 1: Sole cure for beings' suffering, Source of all happiness, May the teachings remain for a long time, Supported and respected.
